awd_titl_txt: AF: Medium: New Frontiers in Equilibrium Computation
awd_abstract_narration:
Concepts and methodologies from economics and social sciences have found numerous applications in the study of the Internet and e-commerce.  At the core of many such applications lies the notion of equilibria, which has been widely studied by game theorists and economists to model and predict the strategic behavior of selfish yet rational agents.  During the past decade, the computation of equilibria in both games and markets has been studied intensively and many of the exciting developments have brought new insights towards a much better understanding of equilibria.  At the same time, they opened up a window to many new research challenges.  The goal of the project is to explore some of the important directions and problems that have emerged in the new frontiers of equilibrium computation.  Research along directions pursued in the project will complement the already extensive literature in economics and social sciences on equilibria, by offering new perspectives through the lens of algorithms, approximation, and computational complexity.  In addition to curriculum development, mentoring PhD students, and involving undergraduate students in accessible projects, the PIs will actively pursue outreach activities and broadly disseminate results obtained in the project.

Some of the research directions that the PIs plan to explore include the following:  1) Deepen our understanding of the new exponential-time hypothesis for fixed-point computation employed by Rubinstein in his recent breakthrough, by exploring its connections with other natural conjectures on the exact complexity of fundamental equilibrium computation problems.  2) Explore connections between two problems that have been studied intensively in the literature, the problem of finding an approximate Nash equilibrium in an anonymous game with a polynomial precision and that in a two-player game with a constant precision.  3) Study the computation of equilibria in games and markets with a unique equilibrium.  Equilibrium as a prediction tool is more meaningful when a unique equilibrium exists.  4) Work towards a dichotomy theorem for Arrow-Debreu market equilibria that aims to classify every family of utilities into those that are easy to solve and those that are intractable.

por.por_cntn:
The notion of equilibria plays a central role in the modeling of interactions between rational agents each with their own objectives. The project investigated algorithms for the computation of equilibria in a variety of settings and the complexity of the associated problems. Below we describe some of the main results achieved.

In the one-sided matching problem, we want to match agents to goods, given the utilities of the agents for the goods. A classical scheme proposed by Hylland and Zeckhauser in 1979 uses the power of a pricing mechanism to derive a randomized allocation that has several desirable properties, e.g. is envy-free (no agent prefers the allocation of another agent) and is Pareto optimal. We addressed the computational complexity of the problem of computing a solution in the HZ scheme. We presented a strongly polynomial-time algorithm for the case when the agents' utilities come from a bivalued set. In the general case, we classified the complexity of the HZ scheme and showed that computing an approximate HZ equilibrium is intractable, according to current complexity assumptions.

We studied the pacing equilibrium problem for budget management in online auctions. To manage budget constraints and smooth out the expenditure across auctions, the bidders (or the platform on behalf of them) often employ pacing: each bidder is assigned a multiplier between 0 and 1, and her bid on each item is multiplicatively scaled down by the multiplier. We showed that the problem of finding an approximate pacing equilibrium (assignment of multipliers) is intractable.

We studied traffic equilibrium problems in the presence of autonomous vehicles as rational players using an approach based on mean field games. We developed an algorithm for finding an approximate equilibrium in a mean field traffic flow problem based on the multigrid preconditioned Newton's method. We furthermore presented scalable traffic stability analysis for both pure autonomous vehicle traffic and mixed traffic (with both autonomous and human-driven vehicles) based on mean field games. It is shown from linear stability analysis and numerical experiments that autonomous vehicles help stabilize the traffic.

We developed polynomial-time algorithms for the qualitative reachability analysis of branching concurrent stochastic games, a class of infinite-state, imperfect information stochastic games that generalize several other stochastic games and models (e.g. finite-state concurrent games, branching simple stochastic games). Algorithms were developed both for the almost-sure reachability problem and the limit-sure problem, i.e. determining whether there is a policy that reaches the goal with probability exactly 1, or arbitrarily close to 1, and computing such a policy.

We studied the proportional allocation rule used in proof-of-work blockchains, where each miner for one completed block is awarded by an amount that is, in expectation, proportional to the number of hashes the miner contributed to the mining of the block. We presented an axiomatic theory of incentives in proof-of-work blockchains at the time scale of a single block.

Algorithms and lower bounds were obtained for a number of other problems, including in particular problems in smoothed analysis and property testing. Highlights include the following: Improved smoothed analysis of the FLIP algorithm for the Local Max Cut problem on general graphs. An optimal algorithm and matching lower bound on the query complexity of testing whether an unknown Boolean function is unate (i.e. every variable is either non-decreasing or non-increasing) or is far from unate. Algorithms and lower bounds for population recovery from the deletion channel, i.e. learning an unknown distribution over an unknown set of bit-strings, given access to independent draws from the distribution that have been corrupted by deletion of bits with some fixed probability. Optimal algorithm and matching lower bound for estimating the number of edges of an unknown undirected graph with access to an independent set oracle.
